Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Being the GOAT at two video game simulations of real-life activities (both of which have all but vanished outside of Dave & Buster’s and Round1 arcades) is a “pretty niche” thing to devote your life to.
Chike first tried DDR in 2005, after his older brother got him a copy of the game for his thirteenth birthday.
“It wasn't anything serious,” he told Gazetteer SF over FaceTime from his home in Hayward.
“I wasn't extremely good at the game or anything.”
In fact, Chike began collecting followers as soon as he started uploading videos of his performances online, under the username iamchris4life.
At his mother’s request, many of those early clips are shot from the waist down, his signature basketball shorts swooshing around his lanky legs.
“He's the GOAT,”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: friend; a San Francisco programmer and longtime DDR enthusiast

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Everybody knows it.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: friend; a San Francisco programmer and longtime DDR enthusiast

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: No one would deny it.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: friend; a San Francisco programmer and longtime DDR enthusiast

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: telling the New York Times he wanted to buy a multi-thousand dollar DDR arcade cabinet
“We’re learning to pay for things when we have the money,”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: his mom, who reportedly managed those deals

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “I don’t think I would have any other reason to take it so seriously if it wasn’t for the community and the competition,” he said.
“You discover this group of people who’s really like-minded.
It’s a really rare thing, because out in the normal world, there’s not a lot of people who think like me or have similar hobbies or have the grinder mentality for video games like me.”
“I had no idea he could do shit like that,” someone uttered in the crowd, in awe, in a video of his display.
Clark had been following Chike’s meteoric rise from its early days.
The two first met in person at the Ohio tournament, then grew close once they both lived in the Bay Area.
“Whenever you meet someone who plays DDR, you kind of don't really care that much what they're doing outside of the game, right?” Clark said.
In all of his years of knowing Chike, he could not recall a time when they'd talked about their jobs, despite both spending years working in the tech industry here.
It’s something that few other elite Dance Dance Revolution players really bother with, Clark said.
Clark recalled the song required about 800 steps at 220 beats per minute for two minutes, a feat of agility not entirely dissimilar to an Olympic sprint.

“How someone can even have the physical stamina to do that let alone have the mental fortitude to continue when one tiny mistake is the end of the run … it’s hard to even come up with words for this kind of thing,” Clark said.
“It's literally Olympics level, astronaut level.”
“I was, like, I get to quit and have severance at the same time — it was almost a win-win, ‘cause I was already a little bit checked out,” he said.
Chike told Gazetteer he’s saved enough to keep him afloat for a few years, helped along by the occasional brand deal.
“I don't think I can physically do this forever,” he said.
“I'm getting up there, I just turned 33 this week.
So I'm just taking advantage of it while I can.”
The mixture of talent, endurance, and the good fortune of coming up at DDR’s peak is a one-in-a-million combination, as his friend Clark proudly pointed out.
“This is the best that anyone in the human race could possibly achieve at this thing,” Clark told Gazetteer.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: A sample comment on one of his practice runs, months before he made history: “that performance... no other way to describe it but... FUCKING LEGENDARY.”
